Outstanding book. Dawkins is at his best in The Ancestor's Tale, taking us on an epic journey from humans back through our common ancestors with every other living thing. I came away from this book with a much deeper understanding of so many things:- how much we share with other life: that the gene for human eye colour is shared with chimpanzees, that we have genes like those for haemoglobin whose beginnings go back hundreds of millions of years- how evolutionary biologists scientifically determine the relationships between species, and when the most recent common ancestor lived- how common parallel evolution is, from gliding animals to echolocation to segmented bodies- what the ancient world looked like, and how this affected the development of our ancestors- how a small geographic separation or even slight sexual preference change can lead to speciation - a point where two species separate- how species is the only clearly defined taxonomic division, and even that is not useful for organisms like bacteria which don't reproduce sexually- why fish are darker at the bottom than the top and how they sometimes flip upside down- how life begins: the process by which an embryo becomes segmented and cells become specialised, and how sometimes this can go wrong- how a new kind of organism might evolve by gradually truncating the life cycle of another, like an axolotl- what the origins of life involved: that eukaryotic cells formed by a bunch of bacteria getting friendly with each other, how hot springs might have provided that meeting place- how life might have evolved differently if it were to start over again, on Earth or elsewhere.My life is much richer for having read this book. I don't say that about many books at all.

Dawkins has written a masterpiece. In this book he manages to bring three big things together and explain them in clear language accessible to anyone. First, he instructs clearly upon principles of evolution. Long has he been a proponent of evolution, in this book he takes us on a journey backwards in time and shows us what we know about our evolutionary transitions from humans back to the origin of life. He covers many of the major issues taught in a regular evolutionary biology class but also touches upon many intriguing aspects of evolution not often discussed. He dwells not just on principles, but helps explain the theory and research behind it in a very plain way. Second, he does all this while introducing the reader to the vast biological diversity on Earth. This book is rich in natural history and anyone who loves learning about biology in general will find treasures on every page. Third, he also touches upon many philosophical issues that are rooted in biology or can be addressed from a different biological perspective. To say this book is well-written is an understatement. Dawkins presents a vast array of examples and research. Isaac Asimov wrote a book similar to this called "Beginnings", yet Dawkins makes that book look likes a kindergarten reader. His explanations are clear, his examples are concise and up to date (at least for a book). Furthermore, Dawkins uses his wit and humor in unexpected places, never have I laughed so much in reading a science book. Moreover, he is direct and does not miss any chance to take a jab at creationists throughout this exposition. I look forward to reading more of his books.

Wow. Wow, wow, wow, wow. I'm absolutely mesmerized. Even though it took me more than a year to finish this book, the cause definitely wasn't my lack of interest in it. You have to take into account that it has 800 pages and it is filled with some "serious science stuff" that isn't always all that easy to process - even though it's put in a popular kind of way to broaden amount of people who could understand its message. Dawkins takes us for a journey, one hell of a journey might I add. Starting point: today, ending point: beggining of a life hundreds millions years ago. He explains step by step (but seen backwards) how evolution (probably) went and how everything (probably) evolved. He tries and without no doubt succeeds in picturing the almost unbelievable variety of life and doesn't fail to amaze the reader with tons of examples and info on how it works in animal kingdom. With every chapter I found out something I didn't know before, I got to understand relationships and parallels that I never thought of before and - to be true - Dawkins made me fall in love with nature and science more than ever. I'm sorry I didn't read this book earlier, because with this passion the book ignited in me, I think I might have gone in very different direction with my studies. But let's stop with the praise for a moment. Some parts of the book were really hard to process, especially all the genetics that were just totally lost on me. However, mostly Dawkins handled the complexity of those issues very well and was able to explain it in fairly simple language with lots of helping examples. This really is one of the best books I've ever read and I know I'll get back to it one day.

A fascinating tale written with wit and passion. Dawkins leads readers on a whistle-stop tour of life (mostly vertebrate animal life, but hey) that goes as deeply into some topics (statistical phylogeny, nearly-neutral theory, red queen hypothesis) as an undergraduate-level university course, but with much more style. Anecdotes pepper the chapters and help lend life, and memorability, to the proceedings, and there is rarely a dull moment--until the end, which, after reaching the fabled Grand Concestor (common ancestor), squibs out and becomes dull and mushy. Apart from a lacklustre finale, this book is highly recommended to anyone remotely interested in science or biology.NB in the years since its publication, many minor details in the book have changed. For an overview of the new animal phylogeny, see the latest edition of Hickman et al.'s "Integrated Principles of Zoology." There have been some big shuffles in the protostomes, and Xenoturbellida has finally found a home--with the acoels! For detail on hominin phylogeny (Ancestor's Tale uses the outmoded "hominid," which tells you how out of date it is), see the latest edition of "The Human Past," edited by Chris Scarre. We now have a richer picture of the human past, including fascinating "introgression" events (gene flow from other hominin species into our own, which has happened at least three or four times with as many species) revealed by molecular research (perfect for the theme of this book!). Other than in those key areas, the information Dawkins lays out here is accurate to this day, and just as fascinating now as then.

There's no way the human brain could retain all the dense scientific detail packed into this volume's 600+ pages, following evolution backwards in time from modern day humankind to the origin of the first gene. Dawkins leaves a lot of questions unanswered, because there are admittedly many unknown factors along the way -- still , you get as thorough an overview as possible of the process as possible based on the evidence available at the time of the book's writing.There are points where the book feels unnecessarily detailed to the nonscientific mind, but Dawkins clearly felt that every detail of the journey mattered.*Spoiler alert*It's no accident that Dawkins models his journey on the pilgrimage described in "The Canterbury Tales." This book is his own homage to the amazing processes that have brought about the varied and ever-changing facets of life as we know it. Only in the last paragraphs of the book does he come back to one of his pet themes -- his opposition to religion."It is not because I wish to limit or circumscribe reverence; not because I want to reduce or downgrade the true reverence with which we are moved to celebrate the universe, once we understand it properly...My objection to supernatural beliefs is precisely that they miserable fail to do justice to the sublime grandeur of the real world," Dawkins writes in his conclusion."The Ancestor's Tale" is his attempt to celebrate and do justice to what he sees as the greatest force in the universe.

Though very little could be more cliché in a review than to label a book a tour de force, there really isn't a phrase better suited for describing The Ancestor's Tale. Well, I suppose magnum opus could work, but that has always had the ring of "peak achievement" to me (despite the fact that the adjective is not superlative) and I wouldn't go so far as to say that this is Dawkins' crowning achievement, though I will gladly label it my personal favorite to date. Inspired by The Canterbury Tales and written as a long pilgrimage backwards through time, this book is one of the best treatments on phylogeny that I've ever read, containing all of the information of a well-researched textbook, yet written in the lucid and engaging style that Dawkins is rightfully praised for. Much of what is covered is theoretical, especially when the topics reach the mists of pre-history, but the concepts are expertly researched and Dawkins does an excellent job of referencing the pertinent researchers and their works should the reader choose to delve deeper on any points. There are a few instances (usually used to help illustrate points, though sometimes just to get in a good jab) in which Dawkins references then-modern sociopolitical topics, which have already begun to date the work and lose their power as examples, but this doesn't occur often enough to detract from the overall work. Anyone fascinated by life and the varied roads down which evolution has driven it over the epochs should read this book.

The Ancestor's Tale: A Pilgrimage to the Dawn of Evolution2004, nearly 700 ppI read several parts of this book [checked out from Naturalis library] before my trip to the U.S. but did not have time to read more. It was quite interesting, though his innovative ordering of the chapters took me a long time to get used to. "Ancestors" made me think it was going to be the evolution of human beings, or at least of primates -- which is what I seem to find more fun to read about. But no, those occupy only the first couple of chapters, and after that you go backwards to invertebrates, one-celled organisms, and whatever, way back to the origin of life on a planet with no life.This is the book I was thinking of that is SO big and heavy -- though the illustrations [photos] really are nice to see.And this is the book that there is a cheap US edition of, without the nice photos, so if I ever order it [for you guys or for myself], I will try to get a used copy of the original UK edition.MomPublisher's blurb:"In The Ancestor's Tale, Dawkins offers a masterwork: an exhilarating reverse tour through evolution, from present-day humans back to the microbial beginnings of life four billion years ago. Throughout the journey Dawkins spins entertaining, insightful stories and sheds light on topics such as speciation, sexual selection, and extinction. The Ancestor's Tale is at once an essential education in evolutionary theory and a riveting read."

With four brothers and three sisters and well over fifty cousins,I already knew that I come from a big family (not to mention the rest of humanity). What this amazing book reminds me is that not only am I (are you) related to millions of people dead, living and yet to be born;I (we are) am also distant cousins to every creature and plant that ever lived, lives and ever will live. If that thought doesn't blow your mind, I doubt that anything will. Given all that, I will never look at an asparagus in the usual, indifferent way again; they are me (and you). Indeed, this book adds new meaning to the notion "Meet the relatives".There are so many gems to be discovered in this book that I can hardly decide where to begin. Here is just one. Dawkins says that if the whole of Africa were to be wiped away from the earth, most of the human genetic differences in the world would vanish with it. But if the rest of the world should disappear, and Africa alone remained, not much would change in the human genetic pool. In other words, people living in Africa are more genetically divergent from other Africans than the rest of humanity (those living in Europe, Asia, and the Americas and so on) are from each other. Also, did you know that whales once roamed on land? Well, if you didn't, maybe you should read this book.

This highly acclaimed book from the world’s best-known evolutionary biologist takes an interesting approach to its narrative. Expressed in a format that is a homage to Chaucer’s ‘Canterbury Tales’, there are no chapters but mini stories as we travel on our journey back through time to unite the branches of the evolutionary tree (the Neanderthal’s Tale, The Gibbon’s Tale, The Peacock’s Tale etc) until we reach the dawn of life itself.Each ‘Tale’ discusses the modern creature in depth and the features of the extinct species from the time when the evidence suggests that species split from all others. It is a sensible way of doing it, especially if he is attempting to appeal to people who know little about evolution but are curious to understand. Recommend this to your creationist friends!Love him or hate him, it cannot be denied that Dawkins is a superb popular science writer proving that academic writing need not necessarily be heavy and dull, and that a light hearted narrative with an approachable writing style need not lack substance. At over 600 pages it may seem a daunting read at first but the flow blends the Tales seamlessly, meaning that you’ve covered a hundred pages before you know it.One of Dawkins’ best, right up there with ‘Climbing Mount Improbable’See more book reviews at my blog

"Look at life from our perspective, and you eukaryotes will soon cease giving yourself such airs. You bipedal apes, you stump-tailed tree-shrews, you desiccated lobe-fins, you vertebrated worms, you Hoxed-up sponges, you newcomers on the block, you eukaryotes, you barely distinguishable congregations of a monotonously narrow parish, you are little more than fancy froth on the surface of bacterial life. Why, the very cells that build you are themselves colonies of bacteria, replaying the same old tricks we bacteria discovered a billion years ago. We were here before you arrived, and we shall be here after you are gone."- Thermus aquaticus bacteria, in The Ancestor's Tale, by Richard Dawkins.Wow. I have loved everything I've read by Dawkins, and this is no exception. Over 600 pages of history of how the humans came or could have come to existence. Lots of forensic biology, tales from different animals and plants that we meet on the road backwards in finding the common ancestors between the humans and everything else. There is everything from how the current continents came to be what and where they are now to how lots of interesting features in different species developed. The human as a species is young, and it feels weird to go back a billions years in the story. This should be a required reading in the school biology, as it helps understand how everything works.

Dawkins gives an engaging history of life as well as the scientists who study it. I read this in two bouts, first half and then revisited for the second half a couple years later. I think Dawkins is a great author who tells stories that are accessible but also very interesting for those of us from a science background. However, he also tends to tangent into subjects outside his expertise, such as religion and contemporary social issues like race. I think the intention is good, but often the execution is insensitive to the wider issue (such as in his discussions of race in "The Grasshopper's Tale"). I think that these sections can be easily skipped over, but I found myself disappointed in the author's narrow view of these issues and his reliance on a purely biological and political perspective to discuss deep social issues. Dawkins has every right to hold any opinion he wants, but I wish he didn't pose himself as an expert giving and expert opinion when his opinion is obviously formed to be pointed at specific groups (ie, the devoutly religious and skeptics) or formed outside his expertise (which is biology, not sociology or psychology or anthropology). On the whole, I would absolutely recommend this book to anyone who is interested in evolution and zoology. I might suggest that they selectively read chapters though, and skip many of the chapters on Dawkins' own opinions.

Richard Dawkins has already proven himself as a great science writer and educator with books like: The Selfish Gene, The Extended Phenotype: The Long Reach of the Gene, and The Blind Watchmaker: Why the Evidence of Evolution Reveals a Universe Without Design. But with this he has also proven to be quite the literary genius.
The Ancestor's Tale
 is the great epic of our time, but it doesn't sing of great heroes, it sings of our past, and of the past oflife itself. I cannot even begin to describe the sense of wonder that this book has evoked, so I'm not even going to try. Just know, that if you do not read it you are missing out not only on great scientific knowledge, but also on a great story.I feel like I invoke my bragging rights... there is a very good reason why I asked Richard Dawkins to sign this particular book, which he did.

Richard Dawkins makes as much of a concession toward the notion of "evolution moving toward humanity" as he'll ever make in The Ancestor's Tale. While some argue that evolution has always been moving towards homo sapiens, Dawkins spends a chapter dispelling the myth, then concedes that looking at evolution as if that were true is still somewhat interesting.The Ancestor's Tale is Dawkins doing something similar, in a way consistent with his science. He takes a pilgrimage back to the very first organisms, starting at human beings and working backwards, stopping at various points to examine our common ancestors with other organisms.The book is interesting, though much less so than many of Dawkins's other books. Other books by Dawkins have made me view the natural world as majestic and amazing in a way that I never appreciated before reading his work. The Ancestor's Tale is a bit more factual, a bit more scientific than other books by Dawkins, and in a weird way lacks this property.There were definitely some eye-opening moments, in particular Dawkins's rant about the curse of a brain that cannot see in gradual differences, but for the most part the book wasn't as enthralling as his other work.I recommend it for fans of Dawkins, but I wouldn't start here.

This is only the third book by this author that I have read, but I am becoming a huge fan of his style. He has presented evolution as a pilgrimage backwards in time, ala Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, and it is wonderfully done. Anyone who has ever read Darwin's On The Origin Of Species or other works about evolution and may have struggled with them (like I have!) will appreciate the illustrious prose style that Dawkins is gifted with in telling this tale. In the closing paragraphs Dawkins laments that "I have not had occasion here to mention my impatience with traditional piety and my disdain for reverence where the object is anything supernatural. But I make no secret of them. It is not because I wish to limit or circumscribe reverence, not because I want to reduce or downgrade the true reverence with which we are moved to celebrate the universe, once we understand it properly. . . . My objection to supernatural beliefs is precisely that they miserably fail to do justice to the sublime grandeur of the real world. They represent a narrowing-down from reality, an impoverishment of what the real world has to offer." --pp. 613-614. No, he saves most of his impatience for The God Delusion!

I'm about half way through.This book has an innovative but boring/inane plot, just as did it's predecsssor, Pilgrim's Progress. Also like that novel, this one shines in it's anecdotes:* Peacock tails and other sexually selected traits are just runaway instabilities.* The platypus has ultra-sensitive lightning detection in it's bill: it can sense your muscles twitching.* Some birds and turtles can see FOUR primary colors.* You have Eve's mitochondria (...and Adam's Y chromasome, duh.)* Swifts can stay aloft continuously for a year, sleeping and mating on the wing.* mammal sexual dimorphism correlates with harem size.* we have the biggest brain/body mass, barely.* Sickle-cell anemia is recessive, and confers immunity to malaria.* Howler monkeys gave us color vision, by a viral mutation....and on and on and on.Requires some judicious skimming, but worth the effort. One thing I found difficult to swallow, Dawkins' suggestion that our big brains are a result of sexual selection: a runaway evolution of an attractive accessory, rather than a survival advantage. Also there's the point, briefly glossed over, that sexual adaptations are typically dimorphic: different between men and women. THAT seems like a landmine, in the context of brains! Hahaha.

One of Dawkins' most essential books, along with The Selfish Gene and The God Delusion. While those books each serve a more discrete purpose, this might be the best Dawkins book to pick up for the general interest reader, as Dawkins merrily weaves together strands of evolutionary theory and essential factual knowledge using the brilliant device of a reverse pilgrimage through evolutionary history.The richness of this book is impressive - even though it's thick, Dawkins, to his credit, doesn't thoroughly rehash chapters from his previous books, but rather mentions that he's written a chapter on the subject in another book, explains the main point, and moves on. Dawkins' writing is sometimes overly dense or needlessly confusing - I found The Blind Watchmaker was both of these things at times, especially with its emphasis on computer programming analogies - but here, he is on his game throughout.

I really liked this book, but only gave it 3 stars as a way to tell folks that it can be a difficult read at times. Dawkins, an evolutionary biologist, works backwards in the currently known and understood evolutionary sequence from us as humans back to the dawn of life billions of years ago. I was fascinated by how the puzzle currently fits together. I say currently for science is always working to put the pieces together and each time some new piece is understood the puzzle is modified, which is what science does. The most interesting part for me was viewing the "family tree" illustrations in each chapter which show the estimated place in time where species diverged to create a new tree. There were a number of interesting examples of species alive today that demonstrate evolution, which I also found edifying. However, I did get a bit lost at times, had to reach for the dictionary a few times, and also skipped over some sections when I felt a bit overwhelmed. This book could be a college text book! It is that thorough. I will look for some other books that explain evolution more basically. Still, it is worth checking this out of the library and giving it a go. See how it works for you.

Few are the books that can illustrate a painting as marvelously as this book. To begin from today then take a pilgrimage back step by step to the beginnings must have been a lovely idea in Dawkins' head, but it made me feel worried that it might be too hard to be achieved properly. Voila, it was a brilliant success.Dawkins still suffers from that syndrome where he goes on & on about metaphors & weird analogies. Sometimes he takes pages to explain rudimentary subjects. But that's understandable when you consider he's talking to the masses & not to a specific group.Of course, this book might have needed a few more illustrations. It speaks about so many beautiful things but the beauty isn't always manifest in letters. I personally had to put it down every now & then to get a hint of what picture is being described to me. But it's understandable that Dawkins chose to include less images than needed given that his original text had an enormous size of over 600 pages.But a fair warning; unless you've got some ground in biology or some love for it, you might be way in over your head. The latin names are crowded & the biological tales are endless. You'd need much to get through that forest of conundrums into the heart of the beautiful journey that this book offers.

If I had 6 weeks and sandy beach all to myself, this book would have been ideal. Instead, I have 60+ hours of commitments per week and my weekends are usually spent catching up with my personal business (laundry, cleaning, working out, sex, etc.) so it's hard to read a 600 page book in two weeks. I took this one out from the library. That's another thing! The ladies at the reference desk are evil. Why is it that the people at circulation are so gentle and nice and the people at reference are total jawbones? They don't like to give it up! So, this book was good. Probably would have been better if I could really mull over every last detail of it. I like when Dawkins' humor pops up from time to time especially in the notes. I like how he takes a whole paragraphs and slides not even gracefully in to a political commentary.I'm completely amped to get over to libabry and take out something shorter and maybe even trashy. You would like this book if you like prehistory, evolution, Bill-Brysoney type writing, animals, and prehistoric landforms and geology. Go for it. Hit it up if you have the time and the brain power to spare.

This is a fine book, although I expected it to be better (the rating should be something like 3.5), based on how much I liked The Selfish Gene: 30th Anniversary Edition.The history of species' evolution is described as a series of rendezvous with other species at the points in time where we share a most recent common ancestor, these rendezvous ordered from the most recent to the most old. At each rendezvous a tale (or a few) are told by the members (or cousins) of the joined species, each tale telling something about biology, genetics, geology, etc. Some tales are quite simple (explaining how log-log plots are useful), some are more complicated and interesting, e.g. describing how first self-replicating molecules could have appeared.The biggest problem of the book is that some of the points that the author tries to make are repeated (and re-explained) over and over again, which adds to the size of the book and makes some of its parts quite boring.

My first Dawkins book was The Greatest Show On Earth, which is one of the best books I've ever read. It was accessible, well-written (clear and explanatory) and it made you want more. So I decided to buy (and read) The Ancestor's Tale. That was in 2011. :P That book is a little thicker, yet also written in an accessible way......At least until, say, rendez-vous/chapter 20, when it's fish time. As Menno Schilthuizen writes in his review - see http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/... - "The level of the text is rather uneven. Some chapters are splendid science writing, while others are humdrum, dense, or even impossible to wade through." And so I skipped the rest of the chapters to read the ending, the conclusion. Yes, it all is interesting how every species is connected, how one led to the other, etc... how bacteria lead to us and other animals. From humans to apes and monkeys over amphibians, fish towards flies and worms and ending with bacteria.All in all, The Ancestor's Tale is a very good book and a must-read if you want to find out about heritage and how old species lead to new. But you've got to keep your mind to it.

I swore off Dawkins after I read "The Blind Watchmaker" due to his inability to separate evolutionary science from his atheistic agenda. It is just as annoying to insist on a total absence of God as it is for creationists to insist on a total lack of science in the evolutionary process. Just present the scientific facts and let the reader draw their own theological implications (or lack of them as the case may be). I got this book as a birthday present though so I was obligated to read it and was mildly surprised at its enjoyability. I think there are a couple of reasons why this book is a little less annoying. First off, Dawkins allows a research assistant to write some of the trickier scientific passages which is good because his science is not always the strongest. Secondly, the book covers all of life and not just human evolution which plays to Dawkins' strengths as a Zoologist. Dawkins has an extensive knowledge of a wide range of evolutionarily peculiar critters that I had no idea even existed and it was a great pleasure to read about and discover them. Still I hope I don't get another Dawkins. I much prefer something by Matt Ridley or Jared Diamond (just a hint).

A journey that end in one of my best sources for "did you know" wonderment in humans, animal and all the bits that came before. Have you ever considered why a cell blast that has identical cells splitting suddenly starts forming lungs, hips and a head? Or about why there are so many types eyes on living things? Dawkins answers question I never knew to ask.I waltz with his writing. On one hand loving the way he will introduce the known science and start revealing debates in such a way that you have time to get involved - developing your own theory like you would in a good dectective novel. And then I find my frustration as he fogs science with his personal soap box over the lack of God and religious thoughts impact on science. In so many ways in my top 10 books (bought many for gift) yet I can't drag myself into another one of his books. This because of the bitter taste left at the end of the long informational epic journey that melted into the fuming of a whinny man that couldn't just let the greatness of his book speak for its self.Be enlightened by the writing caffine in the main book and skip the dregs at the end.

I'm finally convinced of evolution - completely. His discussion of phylogenetics and the tree of life (meaning the evolutionary tree of descendency) is really what made the most sense, including how we share so much genetic heritage with the other organisms on this planet. We are products of this world, descended from apes. Aside from our repugnancy to the behavior of apes, there is however a general beauty to the elegance and diversity of the evolutionary plan, this is expressed by Erasmus Darwin, the grandfather of Charles Darwin and is quoted from 'Darwin Among the Machines', (I particularly like the last sentence) :"The world itself might have been generated, rather than created; that is, it might have been gradually produced from very small beginnings, increasing by the activity of its inherent principles, rather than by a sudden evolution of the whole by the Almight fiat " 1974 ... "What a magnificent idea of the infinite power of THE GREAT ARCHITECT! THE CAUSE OF CAUSES! PARENT OF PARENTS! ENS ENTIUM! For if we may compare infinities, it would seem to require a greater infinity of power to cause the cause of effects, than to cause the effects themselves."

I loved this book! I learned so much from it -- my knowledge of evolutionary biology pretty much stopped at a general high school biology course taken 14 years ago, so Dawkins really took me on a whirlwind tour. I had no idea that mice are more closely related to us than they are to cats, for instance!I liked the narrative conceit, too, that we humans are pilgrims travelling backwards along our family tree, meeting up with the other living "pilgrims" at points of common ancestry. It made for an interesting structure.Another thing that I especially appreciated was how Dawkins highlighted controversies and uncertainties, and new discoveries. I came to realize that the field of evolutionary biology has been really active in the past decade or so, thanks to lots of newly-available data from DNA. Neat!The only reason I'm giving it four stars rather than five is that midway through I started to flounder in the technical names of things; I can appreciate why he needed to use them, but it did lose me a bit.

You can't get an ought from an is.Page 433: Bdelloid rotifers and the 2 fold cost of sex. (Not sure why he assumes the rotifer EVER reproduced sexually as on 428).405: We can explain this humn uniformity by guessing that our ancestors, but not the himpanzees', passed through a genetic bottleneck not very long ago. THe population was reduced to a small number, came close to going extinct, but just pulled through. There is evidence of a fierce bottleneck--perhaps down to a population of 15,000, some 70,000 years ago, caused by a six-year 'volcanic winter' followed by a thousand-year ice age. Like the children of Noah in the myth, we are all descended from this small population, and that is why we are so genetically uniform. Similar evidence, of even greater genetic uniformity, suggests that cheetahs passed through an even narrower bottleneck more recently, around the end of the last ice age.What did our human ancestors look like before and after that bottleneck? Do we have evidence of language, culture, bipedalism, enlarged brain size, etc.?

What the hell do I know about anything in science any more? Not much, and so I can't speak to the veracity or accuracy of this book. My PhD scientist brother seems to think very highly of this chap's work, however, so I can reasonably assume that the research is sound, current and representative.All of that said, I enjoyed this book immensely. It's long and in places somewhat difficult, but even a clueless prat like myself was able to overall follow the lines. And I feel like I learned a ton about the natural world, both from the factual angle and from the theoretical angle. Dawkins' clarity of style and no-holds-barred insistence on science over opinion, as far as possible, gave me a much greater and more clear understanding of how natural selection works, for instance. I actually kind of get it now! Whereas before I had the understanding of a guy who reads BBC articles and watches Nova, but hadn't taken a science course for nearly 20 years.Interested in science, biology, genetics, and evolution? This is a great book.

What a great story! This is Dawkins at his best, and I should know because I’ve read almost all his other works. It lacks his usual antagonistic snake-poking atheism of The God Delusion, and instead focuses purely on how life evolved, what are its mechanisms and what a wonderful world we live in. In Moby Dick Ishmael tells us that whales are a type of fish. I scoffed at this at the time, but Dawkins has shown me that he was right – for all mammals a subset of fish-kind (and reptile-kind in turn). Why do humans look so unlike apes, but similar to infant chimps? Humans are merely Peter Pan-like chimps whole adult stage has been lopped off. It really is a fat book, told in the manner of the Canterbury Tales – a pilgrimage back through our ancestry – and it took me the rest of Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and southern Vietnam to finish it, but despite being particularly frantic and sociable back then I was always excited to pick it up. Thanks to Auntie Su for sending it to the Bangkok Poste Restante!

"Traces back the ancestory of all living organisms. Surprisingly, there are only about 40 common ancestors that unite humans to all other living species.6 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to chimpanzees. This ancestor resembled a chimp.75 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to rodents.180 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to all mammals. This animal resembled a shrew.310 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to lizards and their descendents, birds. This animal probably resembled a lizard.340 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to amphibians. This animal probably resembled a newt.417 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to lungfish which probably resembled a lungfish.590 mya - common ancestor that unites humans to worms. This is precambrian age so probably a single celled organism.1+ bya - common ancestor that unites humans to plants.1+ bya - common ancestor that unites all life.~3.5 bya - beginning of life. One theory suggests a self replicating string of RNA was the precursor to the DNA based life."

I have to make a confession first.. I did not finish reading this incredibly dense book. I made it to the flatworms chapter and simply could not make myself continue. I've been trudging through the intense material for months and need a break.Why then did I give it a four star rating, you ask? Simply put, I learned more in those 458 pages than I have in years. I enjoyed Dawkins ramblings off topic. It felt like I was listening to him instruct in a lecture hall. That's the closest I'll ever get and I enjoyed the intimacy.I wish the book was split into smaller, digestible parts. Then I could read a section and check off the read column. A few months later, read another. Technically, I suppose I could do that as the book stands. Since the concestors are connected, I would be behind the curve every time I walked away for too long.I would recommend this book for any life science enthusiast who misses extended learning. If you prefer light popular science fair, this might not be for you.

Prof. Richard Dawkins is one of my biggest scientific heroes, and there is no denying that his books are some of the most influential in the whole of popular science. While I agree with his views as an secularist and much as he is correct as an atheist, he is far more than the angry atheist people think he is. His talent in making others appreciate the grandeur of evolution and how poetic understanding nature with science is unparalleled. The Ancestor's Tale is probably the most unique of his science books, it is not only concerned about evolution (despite being essential in understanding anything in biology). With each step back into history down our lineage, Dawkins tells a tale of a species and the lesson studying it taught us. By far, this and 'Power, Sex, Suicide' (which got me into science) are my favourite science books. The complement of natural history with science paints a grand, and realistic picture of the powerful tool science is, and will be a joy to read for everyone inspired by the wonders of nature.

The library insisted on taking this back before I was finished with it.I was expecting more emphasis on genetics, but this turns out to be a survey of Zoology, structured around evolutionary divergences. It starts with the modern creatures most closely related to humans and proceeds to more distant relatives. In addition to the overall survey, Dawkins introduces short "Tales" about related topics that a particular organism exemplifies. These are filled with interesting facts about Anthropology, Zoology, and Genetics. At each stage, Dawkins talks about what common ancestors of the relatives might have been like. I got as far as the insects before I had to return it.I found The Selfish Gene more compelling because it made a very coherent argument, rather than surveying a broad territory, but there's a lot of fascinating trivia and some interesting ideas in this as well. I will probably attempt to reclaim it from the library in a few months.

“Why would a Christian recommend any book by Richard Dawkins?!” you might ask. Well, when he’s not spewing out anti-religious, ultra-fundamentalist atheistic propaganda, he does come across as a really witty and brilliant writer! I commend Richard Dawkins for his restraint, making sure that this book focuses strictly on the science of evolution rather than on his own metaphysical conclusions. It is an engaging read on the history of evolution of life on earth. But what makes it unique is the way in which it is presented, as a journey back in time through the eyes of Homo sapiens. On the way, we meet our ancestors, along with a host of other fellow pilgrims who join us as we discover our shared ancestry, right up to the hazy blur where not much is currently known – the origins of life itself. After completing the book, I felt as if I had really come back from a long and fruitful pilgrimage! It is definitely my favourite book on evolution.

Very interesting backward approach to understanding evolution. Instead of looking at evolution in terms of pointing toward an end, the author outlines the convergent points going back from man to amoeba. Best explanation of how to look at evolution -- any man living today could go back a thousand years and successfully mate with a female of that period, and the offspring of that mating could go back a 1,000 years and mate successfully, etc., etc all the way back to the first form of life. And although a man from today could probably go back 10,000 years and successfully mate there would be a point where there could not successfully mate because the man and female were no longer genetically compatible. That point would an evolutionary convergence. So it's not surprising that we can't just point to a moment in evolution where a new species appears, because it's a subtle point in time. Also why the missing link isn't obvious. Interesting!

The writer may have won the best award for writing most easily understandable science books, but I don't think along the same lines as the awarding comitte. He likes to delve into anecdotes that has a distant relation with the chapters's main point too much.Those little tidbits of information are often interesting, and he is a talented writer.I could picture him writing a corner in a newspaper, and daily keeping and eye on him. But while reading this book I often lost the thread of general idea, and start over the chapter.This admittedly may mean I am not intelligent enough.Let's leave it.Apart from the point above this was good book.As a child who came from an Islamic household, I always had an interest in the theory of evolution ever since childhood.The first time I saw that picture on the primary school text book depicting humans evolving from a common ancestor with a chimpanzee was very shocking for the little muslim me. So this book is one of my favourites.

The back of this book is heaped with praise for Dawkins prose. Personally, I find his writing a bit uneven--wonderful at times and then downright longwinded and smitten with itself. It took me about 120 pages to really get into this, which was the point where he gets beyond our most common concestors (the apes and monkeys). His frequent asides against creationists and divine explanations for evolution seem redundant given that his scientific explanation do more than hold their own in such arguments. All that being said, it is a fascinating journey he takes the reader on going all the way back to the origins of life on this planet. He does a wonderful job of weaving in facts and anecdotes, as well as painting a vivid picture within each of the "tales" his "pilgrims" tell the reader (he uses the Canterbury Tales as a model for the telling of our evolutionary history). His passion and knowledge are infectious.

What's there to say? Another Biologically, historical account of the natural world. Somewhat more detailed then say The Greatest Show on Earth, however,still lacking in some areas. But then I believe he does try to cater for all manner of potential readers, and everyone is obviously able to do their own further research if so desired. I do find it unfortunate that Dawkins writings often seem to be laced with his well honed arrogant superiority, pointedly aimed at certain individuals. And there always seems to be this underlying mentality his are the only facts worth heeding. I'm sure this isn't really the case as he often expresses his admiration for a number of scientist, it does come across quite strongly though. Despite this slight irritation the rest of the content was well presented and very interesting, and there is no denying that he is both passionate and knowledgeable in his field.

This is a great book. I have been reading on the history of evolutionary theory, but this book summarizes the current state of the theory, and the actual history of life, in a popular way. The analogy is to the Canterbury Tales, we go on a "pilgrimage" to the beginning of life, meeting each branching point ("Rendezvous") from Chimpanzees at 6 million years to the common ancestor of the primates, common ancestor of mammals, of vertebrates, etc. (39 in all) to the final origin of life. At each point, one of the "pilgrims" we meet tells a "tale" explaining some aspect of evolution, genetics, or biology.The only negative is some of Dawkins' speculative digressions (always clearly identified as such) which don't seem convincing, such as his discussion of "memes" -- a bit of pop philosophy I don't care for; and especially his political editorializing at a few points.Nevertheless, this is a book I will probably recommend often.

a mighty read for anyone interested in biology or genetics, with discursive bits about geography, geology, physics, astronomy, with some snarky parentheticals about politics and theology.enough people have reviewed the book that a capsule summary suffices: trace evolution backward through time starting with man (though that's an arbitary starting point, as dawkins explains) and examining each point at which a new phylum or genus branched off from our ancestors, going back in time to the beginnings of life. even more succinctly: how does evolution work?dawkins does a nice job mixing hard science with meanderings about all sorts of fascinating creatures (neaderthals, tube worms, mole rats, hyperthermophylic bacteria).recommended to anyone with an interest in science generally; highly recommended for anyone with an interest in the evolution vs. creationism argle-bargle.

Interesting book, one of the more "sciency" of Richard Dawkins' offerings. I just heard PZ Myers say in an interview that this is a better book than "The God Delusion" for responding to fundamentalist religion. Why? Because it's just really good solid science, and as such it is better for instilling doubt in rigid interpretations of natural history.Dawkins tells the history of life in reverse order, starting with mankind and working his way back to single cells and beyond. Along the way, he briefly points out interesting and unique features of each evolutionary cousin as we meet the common ancestors they share with us.I didn't really finish it. It's long. But it's a great bathroom book: broken up into smaller vignettes that tell interesting facts about biology which you can bring up at parties (if you go to those sorts of parties...)

So much to like about this book. What is essentially a story about all of life gets broken up neatly into stories of various organisms that shine a light back toward the whole, adding in turn nuance, cautionary tales, and a sense of awe at the grandeur of life. Dawkins also goes heavily into the scientific process of studying evolution, and if this sounds dry it's because you haven't heard the details. On top of it there's a greater continuity running through the book as it takes the reader back through time, and it creates a great dramatic tension (seriously!) as you're left speculating the details about the point at which our lineage diverged from birds and reptiles, differentiated itself from fish, developed a backbone, etc., etc. I'm left with a renewed awe and appreciation for the diversity and endless resourcefulness of life.

This is one of those books that everyone should read. The Ancestor's Tale traces our heritage all the way back in time down the evolutionary tree, meeting up with such groups as the rest of the primates, mammals, birds & dinosaurs, all the way back to the bacteria (some of which we carry in our cells to this day). It not only outlines the similarities and differences between different branches of the tree as they meet up with us, but also has in-depth sections describing major elements of evolution. And speaking of evolution, there is so much evidence in this book to support evolution (probably as close to "proof" as we're ever going to get) that you wonder why creationists persist in their beliefs.My only criticisms are that Dawkins can be a bit wordy at times, and the drawings included should really be larger and more detailed. Highly recommended.

Ah what an exciting adventure! You walk back through evolutionary history from Homo sapiens all the way to the first cell (and that speculative warm pool), and the stories of lots of creatures are told on the way. Particularly tasty were the cetaceans, and the cauliflower. This is what Dawkins does best, and The Ancestor's Tale is right up there with the Blind Watchmaker and the Selfish Gene.I thought Dawkins lost interest a little once life became microscopic. I guess furry-crawly things are more his thing, but there must be great stories to tell about microscopic life.His opinions on current social issues get sortof shoehorned into the text at odd places. I mostly agreed with his views, but I think a less massively famous author wouldn't be so arrogant as to dump unsolicited rants into his popular science book.

In The Ancestor's Tale, Dawkins offers a masterwork: an exhilarating reverse tour through evolution, from present day humans back to the microbial beginnings of life four billions years ago. Throughout the journey Dawkins spins entertaining, insightful stories and sheds light on topics such as speciation, sexual selection, and extinction. The Ancestor's Tale is at once an essential education in evolutionary theory and a riveting read. Washington Post Book World: "As full and clear a picture of the way life developed on our planet as you are likely to find... A splendid piece of writing." New York Times: "Dawkins... is an excellent guide, both a profoundly original scientific thinker and a marvelously adept explainer... This is an ambitious, important book rich with fascinating insights."

What a pilgrimage it is? In this book Dawkins takes us on a pilgrimage to the dawn of evolution and we are joined by various species' and kingdoms of organisms at several meeting points along our journey through time. What a grand treat it is to meet our concestors, varied as they are in their characteristics, and share interesting stories about our fellow travelers. It is a menagerie of life at various levels and all explained through the voice of science that evokes in us a sense of wonder and amazement that at the end of it you are left gaping for more. There is indeed grandeur in this view of the world as Darwin has said. It is such an important book for anyone interested in evolution. Hail our guide! He has done a marvelous job. And watching David Attenborough���s Life on Earth series alongside is sure to whet your appetite for knowledge and challenge your imagination.

I finished this book a few months ago and thought it was a really enlightening read. Dawkins uses the style of the "Canterbury Tales",starting from present-day Homo sapiens and then taking off on a backwards, phylogenic journey, meeting our ancestors/concestor at various rendezvouses points in the four billion+ year backward journey. During this interesting romp into the past, Dawkins writes of a number of tales such as the Beaver's tale- one of my favorites because of the way it shows how an animals innate ability enables it to create extended phenotypes such as dam building-. It, the story, takes us back to the most simple of organisms; the eukaryotes, prokaryotes and archaic bacteria, showing the tree (sprawling bush) of life that brought about Homo sapiens. A really great and interesting read.

Excellent book on understanding the processes of evolution and even some mind-blowing implications. Hell, I think you could be forgiven for just skipping around to just the tales about different animals (many evolutionary rendezvous in this backwards journey through our evolutionary past has tales about animals joining us). Really, I'd pay good money to hear Attenborough read about the eyes of howler monkeys or freaky-ass barnacles.My main complaint about this book is that while Dawkins goes out of his way to source many facts in this book, he sometimes feels like he's going rouge and firing an idea from the hip. This isn't necessarily a bad thing and I'm sure he's just intending to bring you along as he explores some thoughts, but some people might take his word for gospel on some instances. And he sometimes seems to ramble, which I have no right to judge someone for.

Who needs science class when you can read books like this? Dr. Dawkins takes you back through time, pointing out each split in our so-called family tree. My favorite takeaways:1 - We usually learn or talk about the world of living things in terms of a morphological taxonomy. The more accurate way, however, is the molecular taxonomy. It is only at the molecular level that we can identify our closest relatives. For example, it's at the molecular level that we can determine that the hippo's closest living relatives are whales.2 - The origin of life is less important than the origin of heredity. Without replication, the original living thing wouldn't have a way to reproduce and establish its lineage.3 - It's not unlikely that our original ancestor was a bacteria that lived underground in the hot, rocky subterranean layers of earth.

This book by an anti-George W. Bush British biologist has an interesting premise - find the true first ancestor for life on Earth.Using Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales" as a blueprint, with "tales" from many different animals/plants we learn about on the way, Dawkins follows evolution backwards to the very earliest forms of life on Earth.It is interesting, but a bit dense and sciencey for someone like me with little background in biology. Definitely NOT light summer reading. And toward the end Dawkins sounds like a broken record by repeating in every chapter that we can't be certain when the next evolutionary step took place, because the information from, like, 750 million years ago just isn't clear. Duh.

Dawkins traces backwards in time to show how all life shares common ancestors. In the process of doing so he presents fascinating ideas. for ex the idea that if you go back far enough in time then an animal is either ancestor to all humans or none because evolution would not carry out the exact same path down two separate trails resulting in humans both times. Using a mathematical model they could figure out how long ago was the 1st woman who is related to all present humans and how long ago was the 1st man. (They are not a couple and the person changes as you add other human populations)Sponge cells can be separated in a sieve and will join back together to form a new animal! Complicated and intriguing and thought provoking, I had to read it twice and still could read it again.

Some people think it lessens humanity that we can trace our genes back through plants and single-celled organisms. I think it's amazing. Dawkins writes eloquently about a history of life on earth. His prose is lofty but isn't the subject deserving?What I especially liked was that the format of the book wasn't like a textbook. Instead of saying, "This is evolution, this is how it works," it's presented as a series of stories going backwards through time, starting with humans through all of our ancestors. This provides an opportunity to derive unique lessons from each species. Some stories stand alone, some require you to remember the previous third or fourth story. Taking notes is definitely helpful while reading this book.

A long but very comprehensive and interesting book! He pretty much starts with humans, and works backward in time, describing each branchpoint where humans and other living organisms branched from each other, yet pointing out that we could have picked any current living organism and follow it back, nothing special about us humans! Dawkins does point out where there's still questions, especially as he approaches the point where all animals, plants, and fungi joined as the common ancestor. I did learn some new things, and even though the hardcover is 614 pages, and there are parts where it helps to know some mathematics (but he points them out), but those parts are rare. Highly recommended!

The uniqueness of this book is not the evolutionary biological history of the world, but the manner in which Dawkins narrates its.Hopping back in a reverse chronological order, rendezvousing with the previous known ancestor, is reminiscent of the images of marches of groups of people joining forces at a junction, just to collectively go ahead and join another group at another junction.The concept of the narrative is ingenious and is made better by the narration itself. Dawkins is exemplary in the manner that he explains various biological and evolutionary concepts and phenomenon in a candid and yet simple way.The Ancestor's Tale is a book that, literally, takes you on a mental journey to meet all the ancestors of humans, right to the beginning of time.

I give Richard Dawkins major respect for his works on evolutionary biology such as this one. I still somewhat remembered what I learned from his book as I was about 19 years old when I read it. I remembered how much I loved that he discussed strong details on the topic; The information was amazing to me, because there were facts I did not know until I read this book, such as Hippos are closely related to whales and what are memes. I also like what he wrote on Cambrian explosion. I believe Dawkins did an excellent job of describing evolution with the evidences we have for it. I would recommend this book for those who are not sure their thoughts on evolution or they have passion for the topic and want to understand further.

This was a really interesting book, despite it's length. In fact, it is ode to our wonderful biosphere, from its origins to today, so how could it be short ? In order to enjoy it best, I think this book should not be rushed. Each of the "tales" provide lots to ponder on and always raise several pertinent questions.I enjoyed the fact that Dawkins also presented other theories besides his own even when it was only to (constantly) remind us of the falsities creationists would like us to believe. But that is surely part of what also gives him his unique style. By the end of the book, I was really excited about all the yet to be discovered mysteries of evolutionary biology and I can't wait for all the results to come.

Hooray for science. Delightful and massive. Dawkins spews horrible, racist, sexist public commentary, and I generally try to boycott abusive authors regardless of what they write, on principle and to turn my support towards people whose work is marginalized by such loudmouths, those who are creating the better world within and despite the oppressive confines of this old one. But sometimes I am living alone and isolated with hours of nightly tv- and internet-free downtime to kill, and a brick of a book exploring evolution and animals in chatty, occasionally ecstatic narration is exactly the right thing for the moment. Dawkins is in such awe of creation and takes such delight in the surprising coincidence and connections of evolutionary history. What a joy to read.

I don't give a lot of five-star reviews, but this is unquestionably a five-star book. Tracing the history of life, it manages to present a huge narrative clearly and engagingly while also making room for countless fascinating tangents and teaching and clarifying many important concepts along the way. It's impossible to read this without learning something interesting, and it might even improve your understanding of the world around you. If I had to level any criticism at all, it would be that Dawkins' occasional personal asides tend to be dramatically less interesting than everything else that he's talking about -- but they are few and far between and do nothing to detract from the bulk of the book. This one's well worth the investment of time!

I'm not sure what to add that hasn't already been stated, but this is the most eloquent and satisfying book on evolution I've ever read and should be on every biology-nerd's "books to read before you die" bucket list. Deeply thorough and enlightening. Every page filled me with awe. I think it will end up being one of those books that stays on my bookshelf for eternity and never ends up at a used bookstore when I go through my annual decluttering phase as I'll probably end up referencing it constantly. This is my new favorite Dawkins. Don't be intimidated by the 700-page length. The book is structured in such a way where you can take your time, take breaks and read something else if you need to and come back to it later.
